{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2964064,"name":"Allison Conrad","username":"scubadiv3r","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/scubadiv3r/{size}/234274_2.png","created_at":"2021-08-04T20:20:49.942Z","cooked":"

This has come up enough in the REV Control system forum that it warrants it‚Äôs own thread (mostly to help keep that thread on topic)

I‚Äôd like to note up front that I work hands-on with Li-ion batteries daily as a Li-ion battery engineer. I‚Äôve had to go through trainings on how to handle them when things go wrong, and let‚Äôs just say it‚Äôs been put to use. I hope that offers up more credentials than your typical random CD poster who can use google search.

So Li-ion is awesome as an energy source, it has pretty much the best energy/weight ratio of any battery, and is therefore also one of the most catastrophic when all that energy goes where it shouldn‚Äôt. Li-ion is used in TONS of consumer electronics and power tools, and thanks to a lot of engineering and a bunch of safety features implemented, it‚Äôs rare that these devices see catastrophic failure.

HOWEVER

As far as applying this technology as a power source for FIRST, there are a couple of fatal issues, not all of which I‚Äôve seen discussed and I‚Äôd like to bring attention to:

  1. Li-ion is super expensive, especially compared to SLA. Just look at the cost of power tool batteries compared to an FRC SLA battery, something big enough to handle FRC loads would be hundreds of dollars a pop. I‚Äôve seen the argument that Li-ion will last longer, and that‚Äôs true, kinda. Li-ion cells can handle 600-1000 cycles (cycles meaning fully discharged and then charged again) while SLA varies a lot more, let‚Äôs say between 300-1200. Now that number varies depending on a number of abuse factors, which I will get into, but generally speaking, Li-ion will last longer than our usual SLA. When Li-ion gets pushed to it‚Äôs limits, it will degrade it‚Äôs cycle life, typically when it gets too hot. Given the kind of loads FRC would put on this pack, it‚Äôs reasonable to assume it would not last as long as a tool battery might, and even those only have an expected lifespan of a few years.

  2. SLA is super tolerant of stupidity. There‚Äôs a reason it‚Äôs used in vehicles and child ride on cars, they can tolerate temperature swings really well and they handle big amp loads much better than pretty much any other chemistry. They are great to give a powerful option to those just getting started with powering things, and they can handle being dropped from 10ft in the air surprisingly well (looking at you 2013/2017)

  3. Li-ion gets hot, and that can be scary. When Li-ion start dealing with big amp loads, it starts getting hot fast, for reference most/all power tools typically have overheat protection to protect the user. The cells used would need to not only stay cool enough to handle a full match, but they would need to cool down fast enough to be used again later that day (and they can be a total pain to cool). Worst case scenario is thermal runaway, which can result in fire/explosion of the pack if something insanely dumb happens to it, and even if we assume whoever makes this pack puts in all the excellent engineering into adding safety features, I would not be surprised if bots died on the field cause their battery overheated (especially if it happened to be mounted near the compressor or some other warm robot component)

  4. Cleaning up after an issue with SLA is way easier and safer than Li-ion. The only thing you should really do if a Li-ion pack catches on fire or starts getting hot is to chuck it in a bucket of freshwater or get more than 20ft away from it (not exactly ideal for FRC). SLA very rarely catches fire, and if it does spill it can be neutralized with common household ingredients and reasonably handled by students or mentors.

  5. Transit of batteries becomes an even BIGGER pain than it already is. You cannot put a Li-ion pack on a plane that‚Äôs over 100Wh without explicit permission from airlines. Granted this is already an issue for our international friends, but dealing with shipping Li-ion is a much bigger pain than SLA

I‚Äôm not even going to go into detail about how everyone would need the funding for new batteries/chargers, we all know this would be disastrous for low/mid resource teams.

I say these things because I‚Äôve put a lot of thought into how FIRST could implement a better battery, I would absolutely love to not have to deal with SLA anymore, genuinely. But given the context of the users and the use case in this situation, I don‚Äôt really think it‚Äôs feasible for Li-ion to be used in FRC as the robot battery. I would love to hear from others on the subject matter, but at least I hope I summarized the key points of this for those new to the topic

As an addendum to point 2, lead-acid is so docile that you can charge them up just by connecting a 12V power supply to the terminals and walking away. That‚Äôs exactly why they‚Äôre used in cars. You definitely should not do that with lithium batteries.

I am extremely interested to learn more, especially if said learning increases the current I can pull from said battery.

From an end user requirement, I would absolutely want:

  1. really good battery protection circuitry built in
  2. really good documentation on that battery protection circuitry so I know exactly how far I can push it before it shuts down
  3. Probably, some split system to keep the computer electronics powered even when motor/bulk-power cuts out because I pushed it too hard.

I wish I could contribute more, and will seek to learn here.

In the mean time, enjoy my artistic interpretation of a Li-ion battery.

scubadiv3r:

Just look at the cost of power tool batteries compared to an FRC SLA battery

This is a tad misleading for comparing the ‚Äútrue‚Äù cost of different battery types, but an FRC-specific battery with protection circuitry and etc would have a similarly inflated price.

Yeah that‚Äôs what I was trying to get at, tool batteries are priced way above raw cost, part of that can be attributed to how expensive testing and designing safety features into them can be. I would expect that similar cost inflation would be seen in FRC because of how many user safety features would need to be implemented. Not a 1:1 comparison by any means, but it was an easier comparison to make than looking at the raw cell costs without factoring in the electronics

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":199,"updated_at":"2021-08-04T21:39:46.492Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":688,"readers_count":687,"score":232.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":395383,"topic_slug":"lets-talk-about-li-ion-batteries-in-frc","display_username":"Allison Conrad","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":26760,"username":"troy_dietz","name":"Troy Dietz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/troy_dietz/{size}/135768_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20690,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6421 Mentor // TWIST Program Director"},"post_url":"/t/lets-talk-about-li-ion-batteries-in-frc/395383/5","custom_user_title":"6421 Mentor // TWIST Program Director","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2964076,"name":"Art Dutra IV","username":"artdutra04","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/artdutra04/{size}/65178_2.png","created_at":"2021-08-04T22:04:34.137Z","cooked":"

Also, cordless tool batteries have a way larger market size than FRC, so this actually helps them need lower margins to recoup development costs. In general, the larger the market, the lower the markup you need to cover your overhead, as you can amortize your one-time engineering development costs over a significantly larger volume of units sold.

Yes, you will pay a premium for higher end cordless tool batteries from the likes of Hilti / Makita / DeWalt / Milwaukee, but when even Harbor Freight cordless tool batteries would run into the low hundreds of dollars for a 12 V 18 Ah SLA FRC-equivalent, you know you‚Äôre running into the limits of what is financially feasible from a non-Etsy / lifestyle business.

This post from another thread links to a battery that is probably pretty close to what a FRC battery would look like, including the (expensive!) price point ($379). Spec sheet states 2000 cycles for 80% depth of discharge at 10C (~120A), which is fairly impressive, but yeah, FRC discharge rates can go above 40C in surges, which is going to be really hard on cycle count.

2022 COTS Parts Requests General Forum
Best option I have been able to find for Lithium based battery come from these guys: https://earthxbatteries.com/ Here would be a solid replacement: https://earthxbatteries.com/shop/etx680

EDIT: They also have their manual posted for the ETX series, which is really informative: https://earthxbatteries.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/ETX_Manual_111017_Y-1.pdf

Fun fact: it can be charged with a standard lead-acid battery charger. What really needs to happen is someone with some money to burn to buy one and put a FRC robot through its paces with it (if it works well, it might be an amazing practice battery!).

Great opening write up @scubadiv3r !

I for one have the knee jerk reaction of ‚ÄúLiPOs, Yeah buddy! bring it on!‚Äù Then I settle down and ask myself ‚ÄúSelf, do we really need more battery?‚Äù Especially since everyone else has to use the same battery. We are already pushing the limits of practical currents and wire sizes on the current topology. I want a ‚Äústiffer‚Äù battery (lower impedance). My second knee jerk reaction is, what others have said, lead acid is very forgiving. But then I look at the RC industry and at my RC boat and see a 3200mAh battery pack getting hammered with 90A+ hole shots!

Question: What does an 18Ah lithium pack look like? How big is it? Does it need to be 18Ah? I think the above links are batteries of the same physical size which means they are way more power than we need.

I bet we could get through a match with something like this:

rcbattery.com

Liperior Pro 6000mAh 4S 75C 14.8V Lipo Battery With XT90 Plug

Whether you're an RC enthusiast who loves to take their models out for a fly at the local club or a professional drone/ FPV racer, this Lipo battery is for the masses. Delivering on power, durability, performance, and affordability. Liperior Pro...

Price: USD 68.99

It‚Äôs about the peak currents, The wire is a bottleneck, especially in this one.

These are just thoughts flowing out my brain. Please feel free to critique me. Fun stuff to talk about.

Mark_Wasserman:

Question: What does an 18Ah lithium pack look like? How big is it? Does it need to be 18Ah? I think the above links are batteries of the same physical size which means they are way more power than we need.

The ETX680 linked above is 12.4Ah @ 1C (12.4A), vs our current SLA batteries which are 9.6Ah @ 1C (9.6A), so pretty much in family.

Unfortunately, the specs are different enough it‚Äôs hard to do a side-by-side comparison beyond that.
ETX680: https://earthxbatteries.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/ETX680-Product-Spec.pdf
MK ES17-12: https://www.mkbattery.com/application/files/2515/3308/8109/ES17-12.pdf

Size/weight wise the Li battery is about 90% of the size and about 30% of the weight of SLA.

One thing this discussion is showing to me is that if FIRST did go down the Li path it would be ‚Äúuse this exact battery‚Äù, not the current wide-open ‚Äúuse any 12V SLA <18Ah‚Äù.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":199,"updated_at":"2021-08-05T00:21:37.005Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":14,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":457,"readers_count":456,"score":121.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":395383,"topic_slug":"lets-talk-about-li-ion-batteries-in-frc","display_username":"Peter Johnson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":13575,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA"},"post_url":"/t/lets-talk-about-li-ion-batteries-in-frc/395383/15","custom_user_title":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2964123,"name":"philso","username":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-08-05T03:03:22.034Z","cooked":"

One can also look at the choice of battery as a design constraint imposed by the GDC just like the dimensional constraints that appear in the Game Manual every year. The choice should be fair and applies to all teams. These constraints make it necessary to exercise greater ingenuity and thought to do more/better than your competitors. It is quite likely that this is one of the objectives the founders of this program had in mind.

There are many other competitions where the power source is limited. In some car race series, the engines have to all come from the same builder and are sealed so modifications can be detected.

Edited to add:
Please note that the rechargeable batteries for the last three generations of Lego Mindstorms controller bricks used in FLL all use Lion batteries. The power is limited by the type and number of motors allowed. That has not stopped some teams from building some quite powerful mechanisms.

Actually let‚Äôs talk about 6-12 Ah 24V SLAs instead.

Nukes the motor ecosystem aside from NEOs, but will increase power and efficiency across the board.

We‚Äôre not too concerned about battery size or weight in FRC so we don‚Äôt need to go to other chemistries to get more power.

EDIT: 12V motors would still work as long as the controller can handle 24V, and then either limits duty cycle and/or current limits to keep things surviving.

I think we‚Äôve got a few more ‚Äúhalvings‚Äù to go before lithium batteries are powerful and cheap enough to use in FRC.

But I can‚Äôt wait for one reason: lithium batteries will enable 5+ minute matches, which I‚Äôm convinced will make FRC tournaments far more spectator friendly than the <3 minute attention-melting matches we‚Äôre forced to run with lead acid batteries.
